Award.AwardTitle: Rapid radiation and sporophyte evolution in the Funariaceae: inferences from phylogenomics and cross generational cuticle development studies
Award.AbstractNarration:
A major trend during the evolution of plants since the conquest of land some 500 million years ago is one of increasing complexity. However complex innovations are sometimes abandoned by species in favor of simpler and hence less costly traits. Extreme architectural simplification obscures the record of evolutionary history, making it difficult to identify traits that foster diversification and ecological success. The moss family Funariaceae underwent an explosive radiation about 20 million years ago, resulting in species spanning a broad range of morphological complexities. The evolutionary history of this family, inferred from extensive genomic data, will provide the framework to test the hypothesis that species with dramatically simplified morphologies can give rise to descendants with complex architectures.

This study focuses on the evolution of traits that helped plants adapt to land, and that are fundamental to their current ability to adapt to changing environmental conditions. Mosses fulfill important ecological roles in many ecosystems today, and understanding how their reproductive traits evolved over short periods of geological time provides insights into their potential to respond to future rapid global change. The concept of species with simplified morphologies being evolutionary dead ends is widely accepted but rarely tested, and unambiguous exampled from the plant kingdom are currently lacking.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The evolutionary history of organisms typically reflects an increase in complexity through time, that is a series of innovations that enhance the ability of the organisms to survive by optimizing growth, competition and reproduction. Mosses are simple organisms compared to other land plants, yet they, too have undergone dramatic transformations of the architecture of their body, and in particular the way they care of their progeny and how they disperse to colonize new sites.

Mosses are unique among land plants in that they develop a maternal tissue that protects the product of the sexual reproduction from desiccation, which is a major threat to land plants. Maternal plants indeed develop a waxy substance on the hood that covers their embryo (Fig. 1), before the embryo itself is able to develop such cuticle to prevent water loss through its growing tip. Furthermore, the waxy layer is made of a diversity of compounds, including at least two that are discovered and described for the first time.

Evolution marks not only a steady increase in complexity. Under certain conditions, complexity may be too costly to maintain, and simpler structures may be more advantageous. In mosses, the architecture of the organs that produces and sheds spores for them to establish new populations, is rather sophisticated, such that, for example, mosses can control the release of spores as the humidity in the air changes, often releasing spore only when the air is dry. The structure enabling this release, a set of tiny teeth lining the opening of the organ (Fig. 2) is, however, lacking in species that live in periodical habitats such as flood plains, or in dry or wind prone habitats. Loosing complex traits may be common or at least easy if anyone of the parts or steps to build them is faulty following genetic alterations. So-called reverse evolution occurs also in mosses: species with complex structures give rise to species with simpler traits, through a process called reduction (Fig. 3). Moreover, reconstructing the evolutionary trees of one group of mosses, the Funariaceae, reveals that reduction occurred multiple times, and may result in species that are highly similar but in fact not closely related. This is the case for example for species of Physcomitrella, including Physcomitrella patens, which is used as a model system in studies of the evolution of plant genomes and gene functions. The other two species of this genus are almost identical in that they lack many complex traits (Fig. 4), but they are in fact descendants of distinct ancestors. Consequently, morphological similarity may be a poor indicator of relationship, especially for taxa that have undergone severe reduction. Genetic traits may be offer more reliable signatures of shared ancestry, and inferences from hundreds of genes indeed resolve many taxa with reduced morphologies as independent lineages, highlighting the how vulnerable complex traits may be to loss but also how advantageous simplified body plans may be since various species persist without complex traits. With a robust evolutionary history at hand, the opportunity arises to explore the genetic networks underlying morphological transformations, and compare the genetic changes that resulted in loss of complex traits, using the family Funariaceae for which critical genomic tools are developed and resource are available, as a model for land plants.

This project provided opportunities for several undergraduate students to acquire out of the classroom learning and research experiences and also introduce them to science communication by presenting their work. Two researchers participated in this project and developed their professional skills that ultimately contributed to their ability to secure academic positions. A one day workshop aimed at biology high school teachers emphasized the suitability of mosses to demonstrate various topics in plant reproductive biology, plant competitive behavior and plant anatomy. Finally, participants engaged in broadening the awareness of citizens in the state and abroad of one component of their local biodiversity that is typically overlooked despite its ecological and evolutionary significance.
